The '''Lefnui''' was the westernmost river of southern [[Gondor]].<ref name="Map">{{UT|Map}}</ref>

== Course ==
The ''Lefnui'' flowed from its source in the far west of the [[White Mountains]] southwest in a partially erratic course through the lands west of the hills of [[Pinnath Gelin]], until it emptied into the [[Bay of Belfalas]] through a long narrow firth.<ref name="Map"/> It was the longest and broadest of the five rivers [[Erui]], [[Sirith]], [[Serni]], [[Morthond]] and ''Lefnui''. The ''Lefnui'' formed the western border of Gondor, because the [[Númenóreans]] had never established permanent settlements in the promontory of [[Andrast]] to its west where they only kept a coast-guard force and beacons at the end of the cape of Andrast.<ref name="Rivers">{{VT|42a}}, entry '''''Levnui''''', p. 14</ref>

== History ==
The Lefnui played little part in history, though it was remembered by the people of Gondor and the [[Men]] of [[Rohan]]. When the [[Dunlendings]] invaded Rohan<ref name="Eorl">{{App|Eorl}}, entry for King Helm, pp. 1066-67</ref> in {{TA|2758}},<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 2758, p. 1088</ref> during the rule of King [[Helm]] of Rohan and Steward [[Beren (Steward of Gondor)|Beren]] of Gondor,<ref>{{App|Stewards}}, entry for Steward Beren, p. 1054</ref> they were aided by Gondor's enemies from the south, the [[Corsairs of Umbar]]<ref name="Eorl"/>. These sea-going marauders landed at Lefnui's mouth on their mission to overrun and destroy the [[Rohirrim]], though they would eventually be defeated.<ref name="Eorl"/>

==Etymology==
''Lefnui'' (also spelt ''Levnui'') is a [[Sindarin]] name, which is said to mean "fifth". It received its name, because it was the fifth river south of the White Mountains in Gondor counting the rivers westwards from the [[Anduin]] after the rivers ''Erui'', ''Sirith'', ''Serni'' and ''Morthond''.<ref name="Rivers"/>

==Other versions of the legendarium==
In the "working map" that [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] used while writing ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' this river had the name ''Lhefneg''.<ref>{{WR|3|XIV}}, West, p. 434</ref>
